question_paper.question_paper_name: IIT M DIPLOMA QUIZ2 EXAM QPF1 10 July 2022
question_paper.question_paper_description: 2022 July: IIT M DIPLOMA QUIZ2 EXAM QP

questions.question_text_1: Which of these situations is likely to cause high bargaining power of suppliers?
question_texts: Which of these situations is likely to cause high bargaining power of suppliers?

options.option_text: Many customers with low brand loyalty
A few large suppliers dominate the market

questions.question_text_1: What is the main purpose of Porter’s Five Forces Model?
question_texts: What is the main purpose of Porter’s Five Forces Model?

questions.question_text_1: In Porter's five forces model, what is meant by the term 'substitute'?
question_texts: In Porter's five forces model, what is meant by the term 'substitute'?

options.option_text: A substitute is an alternative product or service that performs the samefunction for the consumer
A substitute refers to an alternative manufacturing process
A substitute is a rival firm offering the same products
A substitute is something else consumers would rather spend their money on

questions.question_text_1: When a company launched a product, its price was Rs.10,000 per unit. After a couple of months, the price of the product was set to Rs. 8,000 per unit. Currently, the product sells at Rs. 5,000 per unit. Then what pricing strategy has the company adopted?
question_texts: When a company launched a product, its price was Rs.10,000 per unit. After a couple of months, the price of the product was set to Rs. 8,000 per unit. Currently, the product sells at Rs. 5,000 per unit. Then what pricing strategy has the company adopted?

questions.question_text_1: Milo has some new competition in the sales of dresses for Diwali. To prevent the competition from being sustainable, Milo puts a notice in the window advertising a half-price sale. What tactic is Milo using here?
question_texts: Milo has some new competition in the sales of dresses for Diwali. To prevent the competition from being sustainable, Milo puts a notice in the window advertising a half-price sale. What tactic is Milo using here?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is not a fixed cost?
question_texts: Which of the following is not a fixed cost?

options.option_text: Monthly rent of Rs. 1000 contractually specified in a one-year lease
An insurance premium of Rs. 50 per year paid last month
A lawyer’s retainer of Rs. 500 per year

questions.question_text_1: Demand is inelastic when
question_texts: Demand is inelastic when

options.option_text: A leftward shift of the supply curve raises the total revenue
The good in question has close substitutes
The smaller angle between the vertical axis and the demand curve is less than45 degrees
Large shifts in the supply curve lead to only small changes in price

questions.question_text_1: Producers’ total revenue will decrease if
question_texts: Producers’ total revenue will decrease if

options.option_text: The price rises and demand is inelastic
Income increases and the good is a normal good
The price rises and demand is elastic
Income falls and the good is an inferior good

questions.question_text_1: If a fall in the price of item-A increases the quantity demanded of item-B, then which of the following statements is correct
question_texts: If a fall in the price of item-A increases the quantity demanded of item-B, then which of the following statements is correct

options.option_text: B is a substitute for A, but A is a complement to B
A is a substitute for B, but B is a complement to A

questions.question_text_1: Last year, Mr. X achieved the title “Richest Man in Asia” for the first time and his happiness was Z utils. This year, Mr. X retained the title of “Richest Man in Asia” and his happiness is Y utils. If Z>Y, then this is an example of what?
question_texts: Last year, Mr. X achieved the title “Richest Man in Asia” for the first time and his happiness was Z utils. This year, Mr. X retained the title of “Richest Man in Asia” and his happiness is Y utils. If Z>Y, then this is an example of what?

questions.question_text_1: If total utility increases, marginal utility _________
question_texts: If total utility increases, marginal utility _________

options.option_text: Must be increasing at an increasing rate

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following transactions will improve the quick ratio (choose all that are applicable)?
question_texts: Which of the following transactions will improve the quick ratio (choose all that are applicable)?

options.option_text: Issue of new shares for cash

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are Implicit costs for a firm (choose all that is applicable)?
question_texts: Which of the following are Implicit costs for a firm (choose all that is applicable)?

options.option_text: The cost of worker wages and salaries
The cost paid for leasing a building for production
The cost paid for production supplies
The cost of wages foregone by the owner of the firm

questions.question_text_1: Economies and diseconomies of scale explain why the
question_texts: Economies and diseconomies of scale explain why the

options.option_text: Short-run average fixed cost curve declines so long as output increases
Marginal cost curve must intersect the minimum point of the firm’s averagetotal cost curve
Long-run average total cost curve is typically U-shaped
Short-run average variable cost curve is U-Shaped

questions.question_text_1: Suppose a customer who purchases only two goods is making a utility-maximizing choice and the price of one of the goods increases. What will happen (choose all that are applicable)?
question_texts: Suppose a customer who purchases only two goods is making a utility-maximizing choice and the price of one of the goods increases. What will happen (choose all that are applicable)?

options.option_text: The consumer’s purchasing power will decrease
The consumer’s total utility will increase
The consumer’s money income will increase

questions.question_text_1: Kumbak is hungry and has decided to eat roti at his mess. His total joy after eating the first roti is 20 happiness points. He is still hungry and so he eats another roti, and the total happiness increases to 25 happiness points. Kumbak is still hungry and eats two more roties. His third roti makes his total happiness points as 27. His fourth roti makes it 29 points. Then, suddenly his friend Lakshman enters the mess and decides to join him. So Kumbak decides to eat a fifth and sixth roti which makes his happiness points become 23. Then what is the marginal utility at Kumbak’s ideal number of roties?
question_texts: Kumbak is hungry and has decided to eat roti at his mess. His total joy after eating the first roti is 20 happiness points. He is still hungry and so he eats another roti, and the total happiness increases to 25 happiness points. Kumbak is still hungry and eats two more roties. His third roti makes his total happiness points as 27. His fourth roti makes it 29 points. Then, suddenly his friend Lakshman enters the mess and decides to join him. So Kumbak decides to eat a fifth and sixth roti which makes his happiness points become 23. Then what is the marginal utility at Kumbak’s ideal number of roties?

questions.question_text_1: The consumption basket of a person for Month-1 and Month-2 is provided in the table below. Given this information, if the income for the person has changed from Rs. 8000 in Month-1 to Rs. 10000 in Month-2, then which of the following statements are true with respect to income elasticity (choose all those that are applicable)?

questions.question_text_1: If gross profit = net profit + x, which of the following statements is/ are true? (select all that is applicable)
question_texts: If gross profit = net profit + x, which of the following statements is/ are true? (select all that is applicable)

options.option_text: “X” includes cost of goods sold (e.g.: building, equipment, etc.)
“X” includes cost of expenses (e.g.: operating, interest, taxes, etc.)
